text: [Music]
hello I'm Ben a cloud support engineer
here at AWS office in Sydney today I'm
going to show you how to get worker
notes to join an Amazon elastic
kubernetes service cluster let's get
started step one you can use the AWS
System Manager automation WR book to
identify common issues
after log to the ads Management console
navigate to the system manager
console then select the automation from
navigation pan select execute automation
from the search bar enter troubleshoot
eks worker no and then press the enter
key select AWS support troubleshoot eks
work note wrong
book choose next at the bottom of the
page select the ec2 instance that must
join the eks cluster from the list
specify the name of your e cluster and
then choose
execute check the output section to find
out the rule cost of the
issue step two confirm that the Amazon
VPC for your e cluster has DNS host
names and DNS resolution turned
on open the Amazon VPC console in the
navigation pan choose your vpcs select
the VPC that you want to addit under the
details tab check if DNS host names and
DNS resolution are turned on if they
aren't turned on select actions edit VPC
settings to activate both attributes
choose save
changes step three now you must confirm
that the instance profiles worker notes
have the right
permissions open the Amazon ec2 console
in the navigation pan choose
instances select the ec2 instance that
must join the eks cluster from the
detail tab choose the IM
row make sure that the following three
IM policies were attached to the IM
row step four verify that the user data
is correct for your worker
nodes open the Amazon ec2 console in the
navigation pan choose the instances
select the ec2 instance that must join
the eks cluster choose actions instance
settings
edit user data from current user data
section you can confirm that the
following settings are
correct step five verify that the
networking is config correctly for your
Amazon VPC
subnets open the Amazon VPC console in
the navigation pan choose your vpcs
select the VPC that the worker node is
sitting in from the resource map verify
that the public and private subnets have
the correct routes to the internet if
you create a fully private cluster be
sure you have following VPC end
points step six verify that worker notes
are in the same Amazon VPC as your eks
cluster open the Amazon eks cluster
console select your cluster from the
networking
session identify the subnet that are
associate with your cluster open the
Amazon ec2 console in the navigation pan
choose
instances select the worker
node from the networking
session identify the subnet ID is from
the eks cluster subnets
step seven verify the AWS o config map
is correctly config with the worker nose
IM
Row open the Amazon ec2 console in the
navigation pan choose instances select
the ec2 instance that must join eks
cluster using the information you see on
the detail tab right down the IM row
check the AWS o config map file by
running the following
command step eight verify the security
group requirements of the worker nodes
and also verify that the network ACL
rules can allow traffic to specific
Parts open the Amazon e cluster
console select your cluster from the
networking session choose the cluster
Security Group confirm that the security
group rules allow traffic from the
worker no security
group open the Amazon VPC console in the
navigation pen choose your
vpcs select the VPC that the worker
notes are sitting in choose the main
Network ACL confirm that the network ACL
allow traffic to and from
0.0.0.0 sl0 from PA 0 443 and 1025
hyphone
65535 step nine verify the TX for the
worker
nodes open the Amazon ec2 console in the
navigation pan choose instances select
the ec2 instance that must join the EK
cluster from TX tab verify that
following tag exists
step 10 confirm that the worker nodes
can reach the API server end point for
your eks
cluster open the Amazon eks cluster
console choose your
cluster from the overview tab copy the
API server
endpoint open the Amazon ec2
console in the navigation pan choose
instances
select the ec2 instance that must join
the eks cluster choose connect if the
session manager is active you can use
the session manager to access to the
instance choose
connect run the following command and
make sure that API endpoint can be
accessed Step 11 confirm that the
cluster row is correctly config for your
cluster open the Amazon eks cluster
console choose your
cluster from the overview tab select the
cluster IM row a verify that the cluster
row with the minimum Amazon eks clusters
policy permission verify that trust the
relationship of the cluster allows eks
do Amazon aws.com
service for
STS column assume
row step 12 confirm that the regional
STS end points are
activated open the Amazon IM
console in the navigation pan choose
account
settings verify that the original stsm
points are
active Step 13 if you are using a custom
Ami be sure that Ami is config to work
with eks and includes the required
components open the Amazon ec2
console in the navigation pan choose
instances select the ec2 instance that
must join the eks cluster choose
connect if the session manager is active
you can use the session manager to
access to to the instance choose
connect run the following commands to
make sure that kuti's components are in
an active
State step 14 connect to your eks worker
no instance and then check cuet agent
locks open the Amazon ec2
console in the navigation pan choose
instances select the ec2 instance that
must join the eks cluster choose connect
if the session manager is active you can
use the session manager to access to the
instance choose
connect run the following commands to
validate your Cub
locks step 15 use the Amazon eks lock
collector script to troubleshoot
arrows open the Amazon e E2 console in
the navigation pan choose
instances select the ec2 instance that
must join the eks cluster choose connect
if the session manager is active you can
use the session manager to access to the
instance choose connect R the following
commands to collect no
logs so now you know how to get worker
notes to join an eks cluster
thanks for watching and happy cloud
computing from all of us here at AWS
[Music]
